Problem 2

Prove Theorem 3.4.5. (Hint: this is similar, but not identical, to the proof of Theorem 3.3.1).

Theorem (3.4.5)

Let (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​) be a metric space, and let (Y,dY)\p{Y, d_Y}(Y,dY​) be a complete metric space. The space (C(X→Y),dB(X→Y)∣C(X→Y)×C(X→Y))\p{C\p{X \to Y}, \left. d_{B\p{X \to Y}} \right\rvert_{C\p{X \to Y} \times C\p{X \to Y}}}(C(X→Y),dB(X→Y)​∣∣​C(X→Y)×C(X→Y)​) is a complete subspace of (B(X→Y),dB(X→Y))\p{B\p{X \to Y}, d_{B\p{X \to Y}}}(B(X→Y),dB(X→Y)​). In other words, every Cauchy sequence of functions in C(X→Y)C\p{X \to Y}C(X→Y) converges to a function in C(X→Y)C\p{X \to Y}C(X→Y).
Solution.

Let (f(n))n\p{f^{\p{n}}}_n(f(n))n​ be a Cauchy sequence in C(X→Y)C\p{X \to Y}C(X→Y). Then given x∈Xx \in Xx∈X and ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that for any n,m≥Nn, m \geq Nn,m≥N, we have

dY(f(n)(x),f(m)(x))≤sup⁡z∈XdY(f(n)(z),f(m)(z))=dB(X→Y)(f(n),f(m))<ε.d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, f^{\p{m}}\p{x}} \leq \sup_{z \in X} d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{z}, f^{\p{m}}\p{z}} = d_{B\p{X \to Y}}\p{f^{\p{n}}, f^{\p{m}}} < \varepsilon.dY​(f(n)(x),f(m)(x))≤z∈Xsup​dY​(f(n)(z),f(m)(z))=dB(X→Y)​(f(n),f(m))<ε.

In particular, this shows that for every x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, (f(n)(x))n\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}}_n(f(n)(x))n​ is a Cauchy sequence in YYY, so by completeness, it converges. Define

f(x)≔lim⁡n→∞f(n)(x).f\p{x} \coloneqq \lim_{n\to\infty} f^{\p{n}}\p{x}.f(x):=n→∞lim​f(n)(x).

Notice that if f(n)→ff^{\p{n}} \to ff(n)→f uniformly, then because each f(n)f^{\p{n}}f(n) is continuous and bounded, fff itself is automatically continuous and bounded. Thus, it remains to prove uniform convergence.

Let ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0. As before, there exists N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that

n,m≥N  ⟹  sup⁡z∈XdY(f(n)(z),f(m)(z))<ε2.(∗)n, m \geq N \implies \sup_{z \in X} d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{z}, f^{\p{m}}\p{z}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{2}. \tag{$*$}n,m≥N⟹z∈Xsup​dY​(f(n)(z),f(m)(z))<2ε​.(∗)

On the other hand, by pointwise convergence, for any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, there exists Nx∈NN_x \in \NNx​∈N such that

n≥Nx  ⟹  dY(f(n)(x),f(x))<ε2.(†)n \geq N_x \implies d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, f\p{x}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{2}. \tag{$\dagger$}n≥Nx​⟹dY​(f(n)(x),f(x))<2ε​.(†)

Fix n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N and x∈Xx \in Xx∈X. Set mx=max⁡{N,Nx}m_x = \max\set{N, N_x}mx​=max{N,Nx​}, so by the triangle inequality,

dY(f(x),f(n)(x))≤dY(f(n)(x),f(mx)(x))+dY(f(mx)(x),f(x)).\begin{aligned} d_Y\p{f\p{x}, f^{\p{n}}\p{x}} &\leq d_Y\p{f^{\p{n}}\p{x}, f^{\p{m_x}}\p{x}} \\ &\hspace{0.5in} + d_Y\p{f^{\p{m_x}}\p{x}, f\p{x}}. \end{aligned}dY​(f(x),f(n)(x))​≤dY​(f(n)(x),f(mx​)(x))+dY​(f(mx​)(x),f(x)).​

Since n,mx≥Nn, m_x \geq Nn,mx​≥N, (∗*∗) is applicable, so the first term is less than ε2\frac{\varepsilon}{2}2ε​. Similarly, mx≥Nxm_x \geq N_xmx​≥Nx​, so the second term is also bounded by ε2\frac{\varepsilon}{2}2ε​ by (†\dagger†). Putting everything together,

dY(f(x),f(n)(x))<ε2+ε2=ε.d_Y\p{f\p{x}, f^{\p{n}}\p{x}} < \frac{\varepsilon}{2} + \frac{\varepsilon}{2} = \varepsilon.dY​(f(x),f(n)(x))<2ε​+2ε​=ε.

Since n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N and x∈Xx \in Xx∈X were arbitrary, this shows that

∀n≥N ∀x∈X:dY(f(x),f(n)(x))<ε,\forall n \geq N\ \forall x \in X : d_Y\p{f\p{x}, f^{\p{n}}\p{x}} < \varepsilon,∀n≥N ∀x∈X:dY​(f(x),f(n)(x))<ε,

which is uniform convergence.

Problem 4

Use Theorem 3.6.1 to prove Corollary 3.6.2.

Corollary (3.6.2)

Let [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b] be an interval, and let (f(n))n=1∞\p{f^{\p{n}}}_{n=1}^\infty(f(n))n=1∞​ be a sequence of Riemann-integrable functions on [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b] such that the series ∑n=1∞f(n)\sum_{n=1}^\infty f^{\p{n}}∑n=1∞​f(n) is uniformly convergent. Then we have

∑n=1∞∫[a,b]f(n)=∫[a,b]∑n=1∞f(n).\sum_{n=1}^\infty \int_{\br{a,b}} f^{\p{n}} = \int_{\br{a,b}} \sum_{n=1}^\infty f^{\p{n}}.n=1∑∞​∫[a,b]​f(n)=∫[a,b]​n=1∑∞​f(n).
Theorem (3.6.1)

Let [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b] be an interval, and for each integer n≥1n \geq 1n≥1, let f(n) ⁣:[a,b]→R\func{f^{\p{n}}}{\br{a, b}}{\R}f(n):[a,b]→R be a Riemann-integrable function. Suppose f(n)f^{\p{n}}f(n) converges uniformly on [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b] to a function f ⁣:[a,b]→R\func{f}{\br{a, b}}{\R}f:[a,b]→R. Then fff is also Riemann-integrable, and

lim⁡n→∞∫[a,b]f(n)=∫[a,b]f.\lim_{n\to\infty} \int_{\br{a,b}} f^{\p{n}} = \int_{\br{a,b}} f.n→∞lim​∫[a,b]​f(n)=∫[a,b]​f.
Solution.

Consider the sequence of partial sums F(n)≔∑k=1nf(k)F^{\p{n}} \coloneqq \sum_{k=1}^n f^{\p{k}}F(n):=∑k=1n​f(k). By definition, F(n)→F≔∑n=1∞f(n)F^{\p{n}} \to F \coloneqq \sum_{n=1}^\infty f^{\p{n}}F(n)→F:=∑n=1∞​f(n) uniformly, so by Theorem 3.6.1, FFF is Riemann-integrable and

lim⁡n→∞∑k=1n∫[a,b]f(n)=lim⁡n→∞∫[a,b]F(n)=∫[a,b]F=∫[a,b]∑n=1∞f(n).\lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{k=1}^n \int_{\br{a,b}} f^{\p{n}} = \lim_{n\to\infty} \int_{\br{a,b}} F^{\p{n}} = \int_{\br{a,b}} F = \int_{\br{a,b}} \sum_{n=1}^\infty f^{\p{n}}.n→∞lim​k=1∑n​∫[a,b]​f(n)=n→∞lim​∫[a,b]​F(n)=∫[a,b]​F=∫[a,b]​n=1∑∞​f(n).

In other words, the partial sums (∑k=1n∫[a,b]f(k))n\p{\sum_{k=1}^n \int_{\br{a,b}} f^{\p{k}}}_n(∑k=1n​∫[a,b]​f(k))n​ converges and

∑n=1∞∫[a,b]f(n)=∫[a,b]∑n=1∞f(n).\sum_{n=1}^\infty \int_{\br{a,b}} f^{\p{n}} = \int_{\br{a,b}} \sum_{n=1}^\infty f^{\p{n}}.n=1∑∞​∫[a,b]​f(n)=∫[a,b]​n=1∑∞​f(n).
